body:
I was curious so in the console I did the Math.log(0) and it doesn't return undefined but rather "-Infinity". I'm sure someone was expecting it but it sure caught me off guard. 

> Math.log(0)
> -Infinity

Absolutely, the mathematical limit is indeed -Infinity.
Problem persists regardless of JS return value.

My application crashes quietly so I can't trace the problem. I'm a JS-noob...
It could also arise from trying to set the axis with a domain of [-Infiniy, _ ]?!

If you're unsure of how you should be using d3.js Stack Overflow can be tremendously helpful. Typically I assume the fault on myself first and the library last, because these libraries have been extensively tested. That doesn't mean they're entirely without error but it seems unlikely that the log scale is actually broken in some way. 

So share your code with stack overflow, chances are they can help you get what you need done, and if they say wow d3 is broken then come back here.

Thanks for the advice. I live by the same principles! Frequent user of Stack Overflow :)

I've read Mike's book, it's a great introduction, and I've got lots of d3.js experience from projects. Big thanks to all maintainers!
Alas, this is indeed a bug. Therefore I posted a bug report.

Values of 0 should not be present in logarithmic data. Though if they are, d3.js will fail to handle them, to the extent that Chrome crashes. I'm positive this is due to limitations in either d3.scale.log() or by using the scale to create the appropriate axis.

Calling `Math.log(0)` does not crash; it returns -Infinity, which is the expected value. Creating a log scale whose domain includes (or crosses) zero always returns NaN, which again is the expected behavior because a log scale can only exist on one side of zero or the other. For example:

``` js
var x = d3.scale.log()
    .domain([0, 1])
    .range([0, 1]);

x(0); // NaN
```

Since you haven’t included an example or test case in your bug description, it’s difficult to tell what you mean by “total crash”. But everything you’ve described in regards to log scales that include zero in their domains is the expected and desired behavior. If you can point to a specific error somewhere else, I’d be happy to reopen this bug and investigate.

Thanks for the test case! This is a bug; a recent commit caused a regression when generating log ticks with a degenerate domain. The desired behavior of returning the empty array of ticks is now restored in pull request #1421.

issue.title: Adding logAxis to line charts (positive or negative range)

repository.name: dimple
repository.description: An object-oriented API for business analytics

issue.body:
I added the ability for line charts to have a log axis. It's very minor code to add the functionality. 

And since log 0 returns -Infinity, I made it so the domain starts at either 0.1 or -0.1. I use clamp(true) so the chart starts at 0 if there are 0 values. You can't have both positive and negative values in your range since log is either positive or negative, not both.

I've also added code for logAxis cases in the line.js for the tooltip so it draws the appropriate value and not what is returned by the _getFormat.

Since d3.scale.log does not allow a set tick amount using the ticks function, I've had to use tickFormat and set it to a value (4 default). This hides the tick labels, but not the tick lines. I added a case in _getFormat.js to return the unique way logs get formatted.

Let me know what you think (i.e. comments/suggestions). This makes drawing a chart where you have a large variance in values (One value ranges from 8,000 to 10,000, while others from 50 to 500), but staying on a single graph. We're looking to use this scale to see trends over time for several keys with varying values.

body:
hi Mike @mbostock! i am trying to follow your hint [here](https://groups.google.com/d/msg/d3-js/QCOk9Or7vWI/YTh22CFFeY8J) and use a polylog scale:

`scale = d3.scale.log().domain([-5.0, -0.1, 0.1, 100.0]).range([-200, 0, 0, 200]);`

here is what i get:

`scale(-5)`
-200 // looks fine, same for all values below -0

`scale(5)`
NaN // same for values -0, 0 and all values above

I would expect it to go polylog and return values above 0. Am i wrong or is there a bug? (d3.js v3.4.13)
Thank you!

A log scale that includes or crosses zero in the domain is not supported, so this won’t work and my earlier hint is obsolete.

I suppose you could implement your own custom scale to do this, but you’d still need to be careful about showing the discontinuity in the axis.

Better probably would be to draw your data twice with two different log scales (one positive, one negative) and then clip it. Or to use a pow scale, or to otherwise avoid the problem.

Thanks for the reply, Mike. I will try to extend d3 with a custom scale, which handles the gap, and share it if successful. 

Drawing the whole thing twice is not the best for me because my data markers can go from positive to negative range and back, i want to keep (or, rather, fake) the continuity. Imagine a country goes from positive GDP change to negative and back.

This is probably better suited for the mailing list, but... what happens if a country has a GDP of exactly zero? I think this means that logarithms are the wrong mathematical model for your data. As Mike, suggests, try a power scale, which handles negatives implicitly:

``` js
d3.scale.sqrt()(-4)
-2
```

thanks, Max @mgold. 
We're talking not about GDP as absolute value but relative to that of the previous year. So ΔGDP. Now, if ΔGDP this year is zero (or 0 ± a little ε), then we leave the marker at zero, as simple as that. When it's negative we go negative. Even more interesting is that the marker can go "continuously" from positive to negative domain and back, as it happens in real life.

So i have to fake continuity and the part 0 ± ε where the strange thing happens. See how it was done in the [old version here](http://www.bit.ly/1ulYxky). Shift the time slider to see how the bubbles travel and may fall on zero.

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/3648190/5836926/fc424f56-a17a-11e4-832c-1043b4f62807.png)

Yes, we abuse the scale. We redefine the definition of "logarithmic"  near and below zero. Of a logarithm we just need a characteristic distortion on the rest of the axis.

Agree with Mike's comment on that there should be a visible discontinuity on the scale to give a hint of that.

Power scale would deliver a completely different picture (i tried different exponent values <1) and is not reflecting the nature of data correctly. Particularly i need to keep the fact that every 2x or 10x increase take the same space on the screen, and that is a log. 

See log above and power below (exp=0.5):
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/3648190/5836729/2f12d52e-a179-11e4-9a0d-3e97eecfa653.png)
I suppose that image is reasonable, except perhaps that you have positive thousandths but negatives go straight to hundredths.

@angieskazka Did you ever get a custom scale built for this? Looking for 0 support, and negative support would be a nice bonus as well. http://stackoverflow.com/questions/32052285/d3-scale-post-processing

@kylebrandt yes, i did make it work!
see the demo here: http://static.gapminderdev.org/vizabi/feature/axis-labeler/preview_pages/_examples/axis-labeler.html

Use [Q] and [E] to browse through examples of how it works with different input domains.

The updated code is here:
https://github.com/Gapminder/vizabi/blob/develop/src/helpers/d3.genericLogScale.js

also you might find this to be useful:
https://github.com/Gapminder/vizabi/blob/develop/src/helpers/d3.axisWithLabelPicker.js

sorry for lack of documentation, it's still work in progress
please PM me if anything is unclear

issue.title: Support logarithm and zero values

repository.name: nivo
repository.description: nivo provides a rich set of dataviz components, built on top of the awesome d3 and React libraries

issue.body: Can we support logarithm and also to have the value 0
